Introduction

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) is a desquamating skin disorder caused by exfoliative toxins produced by certain strains of Staphylococcus aureus.  It primarily affects young children but can occur in adults, particularly in the setting of immunosuppression or renal insufficiency.

Risk factors



Age â‰¤5 is the greatest risk factor for developing SSSS.  This is likely related to a relative lack of toxin-neutralizing antibodies in young children as compared to older children and adults, as well as poor renal toxin clearance due to immature renal function.



In adults, risk factors include immunosuppression (eg, HIV) and renal insufficiency.

Pathophysiology



The pathogenesis of SSSS involves infection with certain strains of S aureus that produce exfoliative toxins.  In children, the inciting infection is typically conjunctivitis, impetigo, or umbilical or circumcision site infection, whereas, in adults, abscess or pneumonia is more common.



The bacterial exotoxins disseminate via hematogenous spread to the skin and act as proteases that cleave desmoglein, a desmosomal protein involved in the adherence of epidermal cells with one another (

figure 1
).  This results in disruption and detachment of keratinocytes in the superficial epidermis, causing superficial and widespread desquamation.



The incubation period from the onset of the initial focus of infection, which may not always be apparent, to the development of SSSS is 1-10 days.

Clinical presentation



Manifestations of SSSS begin with a prodrome lasting 1-2 days and include fever, malaise, and skin tenderness; poor feeding and irritability may be present in infants.



Cutaneous symptoms then develop as follows:



  • Tender erythema:  The first skin manifestation is generalized, tender erythema that is most prominent around the mouth and in skinfolds (
    image 1
    ) (eg, neck, axillae, groin).
  • Flaccid blisters:  Within hours, flaccid blisters/bullae form, predominantly in flexural areas exposed to mechanical pressure (eg, axillae, groin).  Crusting and fissuring (
    image 2
    ) around the mouth is also typical, but mucous membranes are spared.
  • Desquamation:  Gentle pressure causes detachment and shedding of the outer layer of skin (ie, Nikolsky sign).  Epidermal shedding (
    image 3
    ) exposes large patches of underlying skin that have a moist and erythematous, or scalded, appearance.

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of SSSS is primarily clinical based on characteristic features of diffuse, tender erythema with flaccid blisters and superficial desquamation.



Histopathology is confirmatory for atypical cases and shows superficial (ie, not full thickness) intraepidermal cleavage without significant inflammation.



Further evaluation in patients with SSSS may include the following:



  • Cultures:  Bacterial cultures from blood (usually negative in children) and potential primary sites of infection (eg, conjunctivae, abscess) are assessed; intact bullae are typically sterile, and cultures of these lesions are not required.
  • Laboratory studies:  Renal function testing is used to assess for underlying renal insufficiency, and electrolytes are monitored for derangements due to fluid extravasation and insensible fluid losses.
  • Imaging:  Chest x-ray may be warranted if a primary focus of pneumonia is suspected.

Differential diagnosis

Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis



Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis is a cell-mediated hypersensitivity (ie, type IV or delayed-type) that causes blistering, bullae, and a positive Nikolsky sign (

image 4
).  Mucosal involvement is almost always present, and histologic examination shows full-thickness epidermal necrosis.

Erythema multiforme 



Erythema multiforme is an immune-mediated reaction manifesting as targetoid lesions that may have central bullae and erosions (

image 5
).  Nikolsky sign is negative, and mucosal lesions are common.

Pemphigus vulgaris



Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune condition that is caused by a desmoglein autoantibody and results in a positive Nikolsky sign and epidermal erosions, blisters, and bullae.  Mucous membranes are almost always involved (

image 6
).

Bullous impetigo



Bullous impetigo is a localized infection caused by exfoliative toxinâ€“producing S aureus and presenting with flaccid bullae that rupture and crust (

image 7
).  Patients typically appear well without systemic symptoms or Nikolsky sign.

Toxic shock syndrome



Toxic shock syndrome is a toxin-mediated systemic illness that causes fever and diffuse erythema.  Desquamation (palms/soles) develops but weeks later, and blistering does not occur.  Patients also typically have multiorgan involvement (eg, renal insufficiency, coagulopathy).

Scarlet fever



Scarlet fever is a condition caused by erythrogenic toxinâ€“producing strains of group A Streptococcus and presenting with a fine, pink, sandpaper-like rash following an episode of pharyngitis in children (

image 8
).  The rash is prominent in flexural areas and often desquamates but does not cause blistering or a positive Nikolsky sign.

Management



Management of SSSS includes hospital admission with the following:



  • Intravenous antistaphylococcal antibiotics (eg, nafcillin, oxacillin, vancomycin)
  • Supportive care:
    • Intravenous fluids (for insensible fluid loss and reduced oral intake)
    • Wound care (eg, petroleum jelly, nonadherent dressings)
    • Avoidance of local trauma (eg, minimal adhesive use, no tourniquets)

Prognosis



Most patients who receive treatment recover fully within 1-2 weeks.  Complications (eg, sepsis, electrolyte imbalance) and mortality are higher in adults and those with high-risk conditions (eg, impaired kidney function, diabetes mellitus).

Summary



Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (

) is caused by exfoliative toxins produced by certain strains of Staphylococcus aureus.  Young children are primarily affected, and manifestations include severe, widespread epidermal blistering and shedding with gentle pressure; mucous membranes are spared.  With treatment (eg, intravenous antistaphylococcal antibiotics), most patients recover fully within weeks.
